The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of major crops, including maize, the most important staple food crop for more than 350 million people worldwide. We use a statistical model to project how maize yields will change in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. These results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely across businesses, and many businesses expect to remain open for a long time. Plastic debris is a major environmental problem, but the global load of floating plastic debris in the ocean is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the ocean. The plastic debris is first fragmented into smaller pieces, which are then removed by the food webs and ballasting processes. This process may be a major sink of floating plastic debris in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is consistent with the age of the Solar System. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all organisms. In this study, we investigate the effect of different forms of external energy supplementation on reproductive output. We find that all forms of external energy supplementation increase reproductive output, but the greatest increase is in species that practice allonursing. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output and the evolution of domestication and allonursing in mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. VX-765 also protected substantia nigra neurons from α-syn toxicity. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn in the brain. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against pathogens and is responsible for controlling inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is critical for the endothelium to control these functions. Here, we show that the communication network is highly efficient and has a small-world configuration. This configuration provides the endothelium with high signal-propagation speed, stability, and a high degree of synchronizability. These findings reveal the design of the endothelial communication network and its role in the control of cardiovascular activity. The findings also provide a foundation for the design of new therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, for epidemiological research, and for informing public health policy. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the host environment. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change rapidly in response to diet, stress, and other factors. The anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gut are a largely unexplored group of microbes that could play a role in the regulation of the microbiome. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a valuable source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. The design of mechanical systems with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in science and engineering. However, the design of complex structures with specific behaviors is still challenging. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design complex structures with desired behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design complex structures with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a major regulator of oxygen transport in the human body. The Hb system is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and miRNAs. Here we investigated the role of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the regulation of Hb expression. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for fetal hemoglobin (HbF) expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of HbF and HbA expression in humans. This knowledge may be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. The development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we demonstrated that SREBP1-mediated ferroptosis resistance can be overcome by mTORC1 inhibition, and that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. We found that the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. However, the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting did not reverse declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. Instead, declines accelerated, partly because of losses of older forests due to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring bird populations and the need for adaptive management to ensure that policies improve biodiversity. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings have implications for the conservation and development of forests worldwide.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a rational design strategy for the discovery of new acylide antibiotics. The strategy is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and it was found to be active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The strategy is generalizable to other antibiotic classes. The results of this work are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

This practice has been shown to have negative effects on sleep, but the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells, but T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that these novel genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV- concert and variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the origins of human culture. They also have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the role of social learning in cultural evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that participates in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE isoform is highly dependent on APOE isoform for the rate of C1q accumulation in AD hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD risk by defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest solid body in the solar system. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The nucleation mechanism of the inner core is a key factor in understanding the formation of the inner core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is a metastable phase. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase of iron, which is a stable phase. This two-step nucleation mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. This work provides a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core. It also provides a new approach for studying the nucleation of complex materials. It is expected to provide a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who have higher negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining characteristic of our species, and the brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process. Despite this, we still do not understand how the human brain represents and processes language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predicting words that follow in a sequence of words are also the most predictive of neural responses to those words in the human brain. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. This approach should be useful for understanding the brain’s processing of other complex sequences, such as speech and music. Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that this black box can be made to solve some problems, but not others. We prove that some problems are impossible to solve with DL, even if we know that a solution exists. This is a major advance in our understanding of the limits of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. This paper shows that the failure to learn from past epidemics is not unique to COVID-19. It is a common problem in science. The classic experiment used to study human response to exponential growth is a prime example.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. The genomes of M. lepromatosis and M. leprae are similar in size and gene content, and the two pathogens are closely related. M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the nervous system, and therefore may be the cause of leprosy neuropathy. Our findings suggest that despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This may be due to the fact that they have retained many of the same genes. This work provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of the leprosy pathogens. (Read more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classical statistical mechanics. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in a quantum system can be completely described in the scaling limit of the system size and the imaginary time. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in systems with a finite size.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. In contrast, the only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development is described in this paper. The vaccine is based on a recoded segment of the viral spike protein, which is the primary target of the immune response. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine generates high levels of spike IgG antibodies and plaque reduction neutralization titers in hamsters. The vaccine protects hamsters from lethal challenge with wild-type virus, and the vaccine is protective at a single intranasal dose. These properties support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This is the first report of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine.

Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is a highly infectious disease that has caused many human epidemics throughout history. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but this was not always the case. In this study, we developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by human ectoparasites during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future epidemics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal behavior. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. Here, we show that the evolution of brain capacity is not driven by brain size but by the number of neurons. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, current inhibitors of TRAP1 cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the target of many currently available drugs. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, the development of TRAP1-specific inhibitors may have important implications for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that regulates the dynamics of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the barbed end of actin filaments and severing them. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. We also find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We propose that this ADF-induced torque dramatically enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding actin dynamics in cells and for designing new materials. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess, and it may play a role in the epidemic of obesity. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. The results also suggest that the brain may be a target for interventions aimed at reducing the consumption of fructose. This study also shows that the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain and behavior are transient and that the effects of fructose last longer than the effects of glucose. This finding may have implications for the design of future studies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous admixture. These results suggest that Madagascar was settled by multiple independent waves of people, rather than by a single population that was already admixed. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the interpretation of genetic studies in Madagascar and elsewhere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work shows that emotional contagion can occur in a social network setting, with people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for understanding the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms. They also suggest that the observation of others’ negative experiences can be a negative experience for people.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact protein synthesis. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on translation has not been studied in a reconstituted translation system or in human cells. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor, EF-Tu. We also show that Ψ can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation on a ΨUU codon. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results also suggest that Ψ can be a potential target for the development of new antibiotics. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust over a 4-y period and are not explained by factors such as depressive symptoms or prosperity. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of the evolution of mammals. This study tests the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in mammals. We find that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in three of four extant aquatic mammal clades. The aquatic lifestyle is also driving the evolution of larger body size in the extinct ancestors of the four extant aquatic mammal clades. These results are consistent with the aquatic lifestyle driving the evolution of larger body size by constraining the evolution of mammals toward a size optimum in the aquatic realm. This size optimum occurs at an intermediate body size where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. This study provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on the evolution of mammalian body size. It also provides a quantitative test of the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of mammalian body size. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of mammalian body size and the evolution of aquatic mammals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. We show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at nasal cavity temperature than at body temperature in primary mouse airway epithelial cells. The virus replicates more efficiently at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study provides insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause infections in a wide range of hosts, including humans, by a variety of mechanisms, including the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. We demonstrate that the type IV pili are required for surface sensing, and that the pili-mediated surface sensing is required for the expression of a variety of virulence factors. The results support a mechanochemical model where the type IV pili are mechanically stretched, and the mechanical activity of the pili is used as a signal for surface sensing. This study demonstrates that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for surfaces. This finding has implications for understanding the role of type IV pili in bacterial pathogenesis. It also provides a new mechanism for sensing surfaces in bacteria. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This has led to a substantial increase in the amount of pesticides entering the environment. However, the consequences of this increase for the quality of surface water are still unknown. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk this poses to the biological integrity of these water bodies. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including white-tailed deer, which are susceptible to infection. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive deer in Iowa. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach will be critical to mitigate the risk of future zoonotic disease outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins contribute to the disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ and oligomers are toxic to neurons, and that they are responsible for the release of inflammatory factors from neurons. These factors are responsible for the activation of microglia, a brain immune cell, and the release of toxic molecules that damage neurons. Thus, we propose that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is responsible for the neuroinflammation that is a hallmark of AD. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Aβ in AD pathogenesis. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapies for AD.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread there. We argue that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the domestic chicken and its spread throughout the world. (Read more)

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge for understanding the kinetics of protein folding and the mechanisms of protein evolution. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of the maltose binding protein. The folding of this protein is a major challenge because it is one of the largest proteins that folds by a process that is not well understood. We have found that the folding of this protein proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct steps. These results add this protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct steps. This knowledge is important for understanding the mechanisms of protein evolution and for the design of proteins with desired properties. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for rapid degradation of the capped transcripts. The predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression induced by sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and decreasing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems evolve in time in a self-sustaining manner, without external control. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of time scales, which is a signature of universality. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and other applications. It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are sensitive to external factors such as strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The role of plant-derived antimicrobial peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural and functional properties of these peptides are not well understood. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent antifungal activity. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide to control plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a structural and functional framework for the development of this class of peptides as a new class of plant-derived fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also demonstrate that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome following mating and that these proteins support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of particular interest to those working in the fields of reproductive biology, proteomics, and Drosophila genetics.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Platelet dysfunction is a major cause of bleeding in von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster binding. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-dependent switching of VWF is a general mechanism for activating protein interactions. It may be important in other contexts, including in the pathogenesis of other diseases. The mechanism is also relevant to the design of biomaterials. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microbes that are essential for human health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, is poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which we call the Human Microbiome Project Virus Database (https://www.hmpdacc.org/resources/virusdb). This database contains over 45,000 unique virus sequences, with the highest per-genome completeness reported for any viral database. We also present a reanalysis of over 2,200 case-control studies, which show that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases. This database will be essential for future studies of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, highlight the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the paleotemperatures of the oceans has been subject to question, however, due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are important for the normal function of the nervous system and cardiovascular system. Ion channels are also involved in a variety of diseases, including epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and pain. Ion channels are regulated by their pore gates, which open and close the ion channel’s pore. We found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel’s pore gates are closed state-dependent and that its rates of activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery are inversely correlated. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the mechanisms of K+ channel diseases and the development of new drugs. They may also help us understand the mechanisms of epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and pain. Our findings may also help us understand the mechanisms of the human disease, myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by a mutation in the gene encoding the BK channel’s pore gate.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the host cell’s own signaling pathways to alter the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our current understanding of the invasion process. It also suggests that the physical properties of the RBC membrane are a critical target for the development of new antimalarial drugs. This work has implications for understanding the role of the host cell in the pathogenesis of other diseases, such as cancer. (Read more)

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly in a wide range of strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine design and therapy. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the neural basis of the merge operation. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the brain’s ability to process and understand complex sentences.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions and tissue patterning. Axin is a key component of the pathway that acts as a scaffold and regulates the degradation of β-catenin. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of redundant genes and their role in tissue-specific functions. It also provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of the canonical Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the lateral hypothalamus. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer nitrogen fixation in plants would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we demonstrate a method to control nitrogen fixation in bacteria in association with plants. We used a plant-derived signal to control the expression of genes in the nitrogen fixation pathway in bacteria. This method could be used to control nitrogen fixation in bacteria in association with plants and could be used to develop a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen in agriculture in a sustainable manner.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. The estimated effects were largest in communities facing the largest threats. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize acoustic stimuli, such as prey, predators, and environmental changes. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the body, and the size of the auditory organs is constrained by the size of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without an auditory organ because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider can hear by sensing the motion of its web, which is manufactured by the spider itself. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web according to its needs. The spider’s ability to hear without an auditory organ and to supersize its acoustic sensor provides unique features for studying acoustic sensing and design of acoustic flow detectors. The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The health benefits are substantial, but the climate cooling is significant. The health benefits are substantial, but the climate cooling is significant.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine or antiviral. We report a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-volume manufacturing and elicits high-affinity antibodies. These properties are important for global access to vaccines. We also report a designed virus-like particle that presents the engineered RBD and reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These findings provide a platform for a safe and efficacious vaccine for COVID-19. This platform can be rapidly adapted for other viruses of concern. This work is a step toward global access to vaccines for COVID-19 and other emerging viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of the ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) in development and disease is well established. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs (DrALKs) are activated by secreted ALKALs. We further demonstrate that the ALKALs are required for zebrafish iridophore development and that loss of the ALKALs leads to iridophore loss. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings may lead to the development of zebrafish models for ALKAL-related diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a major human pathogen is a well-documented event in history, but the details of its early evolution remain unclear. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP. Our results show that plague was already a major pathogen in Eurasia by this time, with a single lineage spreading across continents. This trend is not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available, suggesting that plague may have been particularly adaptable. These data also reveal the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of plague’s early evolution and ecology. (Read more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is of global concern. In the United States, the conversion of grassland-derived Mollisols to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of SOC to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These practices also increase the amount of SOC stored in the soil organic matter fraction that is more resistant to decomposition. These findings highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC on agricultural lands worldwide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to estimate the risk of spillover and spread of wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. The tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this alkaloid in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator Phelsuma geckos. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of this important trait. It also has implications for the study of convergent evolution.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of this group indicates that women had a much more complex history than men, with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results provide insights into the complex demographic processes that occurred during this period. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited, the ability to rapidly identify pathogens is critical for effective public health response. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia, where undifferentiated febrile illness is a major clinical challenge. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied in other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate epidemics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the molecular mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. It also provides a foundation for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA ribozymes, but the replication of functional RNA molecules has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the development of a functional RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. The polymerase can also replicate RNA molecules, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the polymerase can replicate genetic information into functional molecules in the absence of proteins. This represents a major step toward the in vitro evolution of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods is associated with neighborhood improvement. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to bind copper, but the role of this cluster in copper homeostasis and in mediating interactions with competing microbes has not been explored. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is responsible for copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xanthocillins, and that the xan BGC is present in several filamentous fungi. These findings suggest that fungal xanthocillins may be involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in mediating interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in fungi suggests that fungal natural products may play a broader role in copper homeostasis and in mediating interactions with competing microbes than previously appreciated. Tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, is a rare mineral on Earth and Mars. We report the detection of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at the base of the Gale crater sedimentary sequence at ∼3.5 Ga. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The amorphous silica is possibly precipitated from high-SiO2 glass, or as a residue of acidic leaching in the sediment source region or at Marias Pass. The amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple infiltrations of aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. Anhydrite is post lithification fracture/vein fill. The tridymite and other crystalline minerals, amorphous silica, and the mixed-cation salts and oxides are products of multiple aqueous-solution diagenesis. The tridymite and other crystalline minerals are products of multiple aqueous-solution diagenesis.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant and animal survival, but the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the evolutionary history of the species involved. We also show that the resistance strategies of plants are linked to their geographic distribution, and that these strategies are changing in response to climate change. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the disease process is unclear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients of IFN-γ–deficient Th17 cells. Development of disease required the development of Th1-like cells, which were dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to the disease process may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is difficult to model in animal models, and there are no effective treatments. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from human fibroblasts, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential treatments. We also show that motor neuron-derived toxicity is caused by human astrocytes. This method will enable rapid screening of potential treatments for ALS. It will also allow us to study the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases. This will lead to the development of new treatments for ALS and other diseases.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the tick to transmit infectious agents to humans. We now demonstrate that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is a bacterial biofilm inhibitor that alters the gut microbiota, which in turn influences the ability of Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control tick-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is a major transition in the origin and diversification of birds. The study of the early evolution of the avian tail is critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. Here we show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. We estimate the strength of the feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. This feedback is positive, meaning that it amplifies the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. This is the first report of a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green color in vertebrates. They also provide a new tool for the study of vertebrate color evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the development of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) is important for the development of new therapeutic strategies. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a BCSC marker. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways. NANOG mRNA methylation is decreased by ALKBH5, NANOG protein levels are increased, and the BCSC phenotype is enhanced. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in response to hypoxia promotes the development of BCSCs. This study provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the development of BCSCs and suggests that ALKBH5 may be a target for the development of new therapeutic strategies. This study also provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the development of BCSCs and suggests that ALKBH5 may be a target for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion.
