Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most prevalent mutation in the virus currently circulating in humans. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the virus. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are also key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. Here, we calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We show that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. It also provides a predictive tool for the study of the chemical behavior of materials under pressure. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fire is a key natural process in terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is uncertain. We show that changes in fire activity, driven by climate, socioeconomic, and demographic factors, can have a large impact on the carbon cycle. We find that human demography, rather than climate, is the main driver of changes in fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming, but the magnitude of this effect is uncertain. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the role of human demography in future fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is provided to the symbiotic organ just before dusk, when the squid is most active. We propose that this strategy is used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We first identify a set of vectors that provide a sparse representation of an embedding space. We then infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics and to compare the gendered nature of topics to the gendered nature of the data. Our method can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify patterns in text data that are not captured by existing structured variables.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe, after which it established itself in rodents. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate fluctuations that preceded plague outbreaks. We find that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into Europe from Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This finding challenges the assumption of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe and suggests that the pandemic was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into Europe. This has important implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the plague. It also has implications for the spread of Yersinia pestis in the modern world.

The sea star wasting syndrome (SSWS) is a disease affecting a wide range of asteroid species in the Northeast Pacific Ocean. The disease is characterized by rapid mortality, behavioral changes, lesions, limb autotomy, and tissue degradation. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that the virus is spread by the environment. This is the first report of a virus associated with this disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML remains poor, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor are effective in treating AML in mice. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other forms of leukemia. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous admixture. These results suggest that Madagascar was settled by multiple independent waves of people, rather than by a single population that was already admixed. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the interpretation of genetic studies in Madagascar and elsewhere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV- concert and variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in the US. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to convert the original crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this probabilistic variable to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to monitor and predict agricultural production. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key factor in the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotic cells. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not well understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. This model can be applied to other transitions from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in South Africa and globally. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for policy makers and stakeholders in SSA and globally. The results can be used to inform adaptation and mitigation strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the discovery of quasicrystals in the laboratory has been slow, and the first 20 years of laboratory synthesis have been characterized by a lack of reproducibility. This work demonstrates that the discovery of a new quasicrystal-forming system can be facilitated by the synthesis of a material that contains a sample of the site of its creation. The discovery of a new quasicrystal-forming system is of fundamental importance for the study of quasicrystals and for the development of new materials.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron cyclase is required in Rvi. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways, and the role of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase 1 (ASK1) in neuroinflammation is unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages or astrocytes reduced neuroinflammation in the later stage of EAE, whereas ASK1 deficiency in T cells or dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that behavioral inflexibility resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral phenotypes of autism-risk genes and their convergent functions. It also provides a strategy for identifying the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. This is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which result in spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes in zebrafish embryos, and in ORAI1, which suppresses the slow Ca2+-dependent inactivation of the CRAC channel. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions, and advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that the inhibition of active release and/or the promotion of uptake may be a useful therapeutic strategy. This approach could be extended to other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are essential for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth. We also identify a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2. This inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer cell-line dependent disease. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and for targeting glycine import in DLBCL. It also provides a scaffold for the development of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. This work may also have implications for other cancers with defective glycine import. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of aquatic angiosperms is even less understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This fossil material has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature and are associated with a number of conditions in humans. The most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is estimated to have existed ∼12.6 kya, and the most common parvovirus in humans, genotype 1, only started circulating ∼50 years ago. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 kya. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Read more)

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. We estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This is in agreement with the average rate of sea level rise over the same period. We find that the rate of sea level rise is increasing, and that the rate of acceleration is likely to increase in the future. This implies that global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005, roughly in agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is increasing with age, but that this pattern is not seen for all Americans. Pain is also increasing with education, but only for those without a bachelor’s degree. These patterns are not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. They are consistent with a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of enzyme active sites has the potential to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the reactive species that catalyze the reaction. Here, this approach is used to study the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the intermediate, including the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The results also provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a newly emerged coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. Remdesivir treatment is effective both prophylactically and therapeutically, and may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a basis for the development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviral infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is provided to the symbiotic organ just before dusk, when the squid is most active. We propose that this strategy is used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. Suspension rates are rising in the United States, and the consequences are severe. We show that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a 50% reduction in student suspensions. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools across the country.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) proteins. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a major impact on the environment.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of six oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is important for understanding the biology of cancer cells and for developing new strategies for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a proof-of-principle for the use of AI-ETD for glycoproteomics. The data presented here will be useful for the scientific community for many years to come.

In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 50 million confirmed cases and over 1.1 million deaths worldwide. The virus has a complex set of proteins that are involved in its replication and immune evasion. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This work provides insights into the molecular basis of the unique immune evasion and replication strategies of SARS-CoV-2. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema. We describe a new way of thinking about the problem of “selective inference.” This is a way of thinking that is needed to deal with the new challenges of big data.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are oncogenes in human cancer. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of these genes, augmentor-α1, augmentor-α2, and augmentor-β, are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor cells in the zebrafish eye. β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Indeed, Pax6 messenger RNA and protein levels were down-regulated and its nuclear localization was lost in STING-βKO β-cells. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which is a unique feature among RNA viruses. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly regulated process, and the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been well established. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. In this study, we found that YAP/TAZ activation by disturbed flow promotes the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the size of atherosclerotic lesions. In addition, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our findings provide insights into the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and a basis for the development of a therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the fire niche in the United States. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires are a substantial driver of overall fire risk. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to microcephaly and other neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV pathogenesis are not fully understood. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the within-host dynamics of ZIKV are complex, and that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of a vaccine. The model can be used to guide the design of future experiments and to assess the impact of different interventions. Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the main source of coral host energy and the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. However, the processes that lead to the breakdown of the symbiosis are not fully understood. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its zooxanthellae are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids by the coral host is a major driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis, and that this process is linked to altered nutrient cycling. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to systemic infections. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. We also show that controlling the activity level of JNK signaling is critical to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work highlights the importance of maintaining a balanced intestinal tumor microenvironment to prevent intestinal barrier dysfunction and dysbiotic microbiome. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may result in the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. The start of accelerated deglaciation at the end of the last glacial period is a key event in Earth’s history, but the cause is still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the beginning of deglaciation is a plausible cause. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate changes. This scenario is supported by a unique set of paleoclimate proxies, including a volcanic eruption record in ice cores, and is consistent with the observed changes in Southern Hemisphere climate. The Mount Takahe eruptions are the most distant volcanic eruptions known to have caused a climate change. This study provides a new perspective on the causes of accelerated deglaciation. It also has implications for the causes of the ozone hole and the climate impacts of stratospheric ozone depletion. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and income for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, the global extent of these fisheries has not been quantified. We estimate that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis reveals that freshwater fisheries are particularly important for low-income and undernourished populations, and that these fisheries are most vulnerable to overexploitation in regions with the highest biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective conservation and management strategies for freshwater fisheries.

However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate after injury is not a property of a single pathway, but rather a property of a broad class of pathways that are activated by sensory activity and/or elevated cAMP.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. In humans, recombination is thought to be initiated by the binding of proteins to specific sequences in the DNA. We show that recombination initiation in the flowering plant Mimulus guttatus is instead driven by the proximity of genes. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of recombination and the evolution of gene function. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of recombination in humans.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we used metabolic PET, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total activity, to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant (first component) metabolic RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN). In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. The dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from PD and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for efficient translation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in yeast. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally and are found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. This suggests that NAD-RNA is a transient modification that is not required for mRNA stability. Our results define a second 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for understanding the function of NAD+ in cells.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences at certain loci persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes. These loci are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These findings support the use of DNA-me profiling as a biomarker for the prediction of metabolic memory. This may help to improve the design of clinical trials and the management of people with diabetes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The tomato is a major crop worldwide, and its fruit is a popular food. The fruit is a complex system of cells that produce a wide range of volatile chemicals, which contribute to the overall flavor. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the tomato is the only plant species for which the biosynthetic pathways of any volatile chemicals have been described. Here we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the volatile chemicals. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato volatiles and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism.

Global warming and biodiversity loss are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of conservation and restoration strategies. They also highlight the need to consider the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is particularly important in the context of climate change, where temperature is expected to increase rapidly.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the organization of navigation circuits in the brain. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering time is a key trait in plant biology. In many plants, flowering time is controlled by a flowering repressor, FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), which is synthesized in leaves and acts as a mobile signal to induce flowering in the shoot apex. Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. We show that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can be used as a tool to synchronize flowering of host and parasite. This is of great interest for plant breeding and biotechnology. Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the dopamine-releasing system. The present study shows that dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra are connected to other brain regions and to other parts of the substantia nigra by a complex system of specialized connections. These connections are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine-producing system. The findings also suggest that the connections are vulnerable to damage in Parkinson’s disease. The connections are also likely to be vulnerable to damage in other disorders of the dopamine system.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand by integrating membrane and store-operated Ca2+ signals. However, the mechanisms underlying the integration of these signals are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in the integration of membrane and store-operated Ca2+ signals. These findings reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms underlying the regulation of SAN function. It also provides a foundation for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. (PsycINFO Database Record

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have not been well studied. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1), two key genes in the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. This interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivory. This interaction may be important for Si use in agriculture. (Read more)

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor synthesized from GTP. It is essential for nitric oxide synthesis and aromatic amino acid hydroxylation. It is used to treat phenylketonuria. Less is known about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. Here we found intracellular alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity to be an important regulator of alkylglycerol metabolism in murine macrophages. Alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity was expressed also in primary mouse bone marrow-derived monocytes and “alternatively activated” M2 macrophages obtained by interleukin 4 treatment. The lipidome of murine macrophages was markedly changed in a parallel way by modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase expression and of tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis affecting not only various ether lipid species upstream of alkylglycerol monooxygenase but also other more complex lipids including glycosylated ceramides and cardiolipins. Alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects macrophage signaling. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it enables the binding of linguistic features over time. Our model provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge for the development of plant-based therapeutics. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, and it is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unmonitored. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in coastal areas. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may be a major contributor to coastal eutrophication, and that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include small watersheds. This will be critical for protecting valuable nearshore ecosystems that are increasingly threatened by coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of cosmological parameters that are required to explain the observed cosmic microwave background radiation are in a sense “fine-tuned” to a very narrow range. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the case of chemical networks.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoantibodies that cause autoimmune encephalitis. These antibodies are believed to disrupt receptor function, but how blocking this excitatory synaptic receptor can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities—or even seizures—is poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change intrinsic cortical connections and neuronal population dynamics to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. Based on local field potential recordings in a mouse model, we first validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry. Using this model, we then identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we use the mouse model to show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. The cause of this warming is still under debate. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma during a glacial period. We show that this event was caused by a rapid release of organic matter–derived carbon (C) and that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and anoxia. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of rapid global warming and the potential for future climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet delivering on its promise to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved in plants, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes in plants is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce the sex phenotype. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles of a single locus can produce a modular system of sex-linked traits, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple interacting sex determination alleles provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a group of compounds that are photooxidized and degraded into reactive intermediates. These species are thought to contribute to the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are known to regulate redox activity, impact the degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the oxidative damage caused by bisretinoids. This is particularly important given the high levels of iron in the retina and the importance of iron in the degradation of bisretinoids. The results also suggest that the degradation of bisretinoids may be a target for therapeutic intervention. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution, but it is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, are an exception to this rule. We show that siphonophores can evolve from generalists to specialists on different prey types, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of predatory niche diversification.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the distinctive human hand morphology is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 My old in Kenya. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. This suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding also suggests that the evolution of the human hand was more complex than previously thought. The implications of this finding for the evolution of the human hand are discussed. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units support cell growth, and thus are critical for cancer. We show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cancer cells and in a cancer cell-line screen. However, one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT2, and that formate inhibition is defective in SHMT2-deficient cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These findings suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer, and that formate-based inhibitors are a promising lead for drug development. The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized. This study shows that deforestation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in people’s fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to test the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new approach in the field of nutrition and environmental research.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but it has also increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a 130-million-year-old footprint of a sauropod in the subsurface of a farm field.
